video.title: Suicide Squad: Kill the Justice League | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

Well, Suicide Squad&#39;s been out a few 
weeks now, and for a brief period was

even visible beneath all the rotten tomatoes 
and spit. It&#39;s nice when we all get together

as a community to kick the shit out of 
something, isn&#39;t it, always a fun day

out for the kids. I think the last one was 
Forspoken, which now I&#39;m thinking about it,

came out at more or less this exact same 
time. I guess this is an annual thing,
now. Fuck you, February. Well anyway, as
with most pile-on&#39;s, it
was slightly ruined by

people getting too into it. I saw serious posts 
and thinkpieces harumphing about how Suicide

Squad disrespects the noble legacies of Batman and 
Superman. They&#39;re power fantasies for little boys,

thinkpieces, Superman was permanently disrespected 
long ago by his fucking tailor. No one respects

superheroes anymore. And guess what, Disney and 
Warner Bros, we learned it from watching you,

Dad. You&#39;re the ones who&#39;ve been dangling 
them over us like a fucking pinata for the

last thirty years, you shouldn&#39;t be offended 
if we start giving them some extra savage hits

now the candy&#39;s running dry. There&#39;s no need to 
invent reasons to be offended by Suicide Squad

when there&#39;s such a nutritious smorgasbord of 
existing reasons to hate its fetid fucking guts.

Suicide Squad: Kill Rocksteady&#39;s Marketability is 
an open world shooter about four DC supervillains:

Floyd &quot;Deadshot&quot; Lawton, Harleen &quot;Harley &quot;They 
came up with my real name five minutes before

lunch break&quot; Quinn&quot; Quinzel, Digger &quot;Captain 
&quot;Why the fuck am I even on this team when

it already has a ranged weapons guy who isn&#39;t 
cripplingly overspecialised&quot; Boomerang&quot; Harkness,

and King Shark. A King Shark who seems to 
be doing his best Drax from Guardians of

the Galaxy impression, but don&#39;t point that 
out, people might think you actually give

a shit. They&#39;re forcibly recruited to 
work for the government, and, to a man,

suck. They suck so hard and everyone and 
everything around them is quick to remind

them of that fact. They get sent into Metropolis 
which has also recently begun to suck because

it&#39;s been turned into a warzone by the Justice 
League who all suck now because they&#39;re being

mind controlled by the suckiest dude of them 
all, Brainiac. You remember, from Injustice 2.

And much like Injustice 2 and 60-70% of superhero 
media these days we realise that Superman turning

evil is just about the only way to make the 
big boring pyjama wearing bastard interesting.

So there&#39;s a range of different mission 
types you can engage with across the open

world - shoot a bunch of dudes, defend a thing 
by shooting a bunch of dudes, defend a MOVING

thing by shooting a bunch of dudes, or Riddler 
challenges. Riddler seeming about as confused

as I am as to what the fuck HE&#39;s doing here, 
the closest thing to a puzzle in the game is

figuring out if a +10% critical rate is better 
than +5% defense against meringue-based damage.

When you feel confident you go to the next story 
mission to fight the next Justice League member,

not that you should feel confident because 
you suck so much you bunch of huge sucky suck

suckaroo - yes yes, sorry to interrupt, but I 
genuinely can&#39;t tell: are you continuing the

broadly insincere we suck motif of the story or 
are you telling me I&#39;m still too underlevelled

for the next story mission. Because of course this 
is live service, where everything from our attack

damage to our nostril hair length is numerically 
quantified to facilitate the neverending stream

of identical grind missions with rewards of 
gear with higher, more competitive scores,

and I&#39;d hate to find myself stuck in a story 
boss fight fruitlessly nomming at a gigantic

throbbing level 22 health bar with naught 
but a substandard level 15 half grapefruit.

Neither did I want to indulge in any more of 
the core gameplay than was strictly necessary,

because it, too, sucks. The missions are 
repetitive, the interface is splattered with

too much confusing detail and picking a character 
basically comes down to deciding which fiddly and

unsatisfying traversal method you would least 
hate using to explore an overdetailed city with

about as much sense of place and function as 
a great big bowl of lumpy porridge. In time,

I learned that one absolutely does not need to 
grind up for the campaign boss fights because

the Justice League, as previously established, 
suck. Suicide Squad: Kill Your Darling&#39;s problem

isn&#39;t that it doesn&#39;t give a shit. I&#39;m all about 
irreverence. You want me to give Superman an

atomic wedgie, just show me the coathook and 
the industrial welding gloves. The problem is

that it actually doesn&#39;t give a shit, if you 
follow me. Every Justice League member fight

consists of acquiring the magic fridge magnet 
or deeley boppers that cancels out their powers,

and then shooting them a lot until they die. 
And then they&#39;re just dead, and things move on

and no one seems to care. The exception is Batman, 
he&#39;s built up as the most serious threat simply by

being too smart to face you head on. There&#39;s even 
an amusing sequence early on where you basically

go through a Batman Arkham predator mission from 
the perspective of the poor buggers being hunted.

I went into the Batman confrontation wondering 
what clever way we were going to fight him if

it can&#39;t just be &quot;shoot the man &#39;til he dies&quot;, 
I mean, what could possibly top the Arkham City

Mr. Freeze fight except perhaps Magic Shell? 
Turns out, all he does is feed you fear gas,

turn into a giant monster, and then you shoot him 
until he dies. And it&#39;s pathetically easy. See,

it&#39;s not so much the disrespect towards Batman 
and his very scary underpants as the disrespect

shown towards the many many hours I spent 
keeping the bastard alive in the Arkham games

with which this game shares continuity, 
only for this to be his ultimate fate:

beaned in the skull and swept into a waste paper 
basket. It&#39;s like the mere act of making a looter

shooter already shat all over Rocksteady&#39;s 
legacy, so they figured might as well finish

emptying our bowels while we&#39;re at it. The whole 
fighting Superman aspect feels like something the

game is trying to hastily rush you through so 
you can get back to grinding up Suicide Bucks.

But last I checked the subtitle was Kill The 
Justice League, not Kill Five Million Identical

Generic Baddies And A Significant Portion 
Of Your Free Time You&#39;ll Never Get Back.

After Superman gets unceremoniously waste 
paper basketed the plot moves onto fighting

Brainiac and goes &quot;By the way you have to kill 
him thirteen times before he&#39;s dead for realsies

and grind up a minimum amount of fun bucks 
for each attempt.&quot; So I was like &quot;Oh Christ,

we&#39;re Middle Earth: Shadow of Warring it and 
hiding the plot ending behind a live service

grind.&quot; But then the game went &quot;Yes, that&#39;s 
exactly what we&#39;ll do just as soon as we

patch in the ending in some hypothetical future 
update.&quot; And then it just stops after you kill

Brainiac once. With nothing resolved and a few 
billboards reminding you to check back in for

next season&#39;s content. It&#39;s like getting buggered 
senseless for ten hours and then being told that

if you come back next week for more buggery 
then maybe you&#39;ll earn a cork with which to

stem your anal hemhorrhage. Suicide Squad: Kill 
Me And End My Disease Of A Life You Remorseless

Bastards fails on every imaginable level. My most 
charitable reading of it is that Rocksteady are

attempting weaponised incompetence. &quot;Whoops, the 
looter shooter you forced us to make sucks balls,

oh well, guess it&#39;s back to the world-class 
groundbreaking single player games with us.&quot;

But it&#39;s those you&#39;ve just shat all over, 
Rocksteady. There&#39;s no sucking that back into

your bumhole. Believe me, I&#39;ve tried. That&#39;s 
why they banned me from the soft play area.

This video is sponsored by Incogni.
If you&#39;re anything like me, you like

to support local business, and I didn&#39;t 
think there&#39;d be any harm for signing up

for the rewards card at the Buttplug Warehouse, 
I mean, free pineapple flavoured lube for every

ten purchases isn&#39;t to be sniffed at, 
but before long I started getting all

kinds of spam mail from businesses only 
tangentially related to anal violation.

Data harvesters worldwide are aggregating 
everything on you from your phone number to

your preferred series of The Simpsons and while 
they&#39;re technically supposed to stop if you ask,

who the hell&#39;s got time to write an angry 
letter to every single one of the buggers?

That&#39;s what Incogni&#39;s for, it sets the 
frighteners on data harvesters on your

behalf until they forget all about you, like a 
diametric opposite of a PR firm. After a simple

setup all I had to do was sit back and watch 
from the dashboard as Incogni sent the requests

out to the thieving bastards. Within a matter 
of days my inbox and phone were cleared of all

but the desired butthole-related correspondence.
Use code secondwind at incogni.com/secondwind to

get 60% off an annual Incogni plan and you too 
can browse with renewed confidence even online

services that do not involve bottoms.
Again, that’s incogni.com/secondwind.
